para.paratext:
By its very nature, circumstantial evidence requires more care in handling by the jury. It may establish a fact as well as direct evidence, but it must tend to support the hypothesis claimed. If it equally supports two theories, it proves neither.[
1]

The general rule in Georgia is that “circumstantial evidence which could be taken as inconsistent with the direct, positive testimony is sufficient to get the case to a jury.”
[2 ] Thus, the court may not grant summary judgment when circumstantial evidence is inconsistent with direct evidence, thereby creating a jury question.[
3]

A fact inferred from circumstantial evidence has no probative value against positive and uncontradicted evidence that no such fact exists, if the circumstantial evidence may be construed consistently with the direct evidence.[
4] In Adams v. Servpro of Macon, Inc. ,[5] the Georgia Court of Appeals upheld summary judgment in favor of a defendant who was sued on the theory that his agent left a door unlocked in a building which was burned as the result of arson. Although defendant's agent had been in the building prior to the fire and arson investigators did find two doors open, the agent testified that he had locked the doors. The defendant's direct evidence that he closed the doors negated the circumstantial evidence that he might have left them open, and the circumstantial evidence was not entirely inconsistent with the agent's testimony that he locked the door. Thus, the defendant agent's testimony was not impeached and remained uncontradicted. The court stated, “When uncontradicted and unimpeached evidence is produced as to the real facts, the inference [from circumstantial evidence] disappears, and does not create a conflict in the evidence so as to require its submission to a jury.”
[6]

If a civil case rests on circumstantial evidence, “the circumstances proved must tend in some proximate and reasonable degree to establish the conclusion claimed and render less probable all inconsistent conclusions.”
[7] This would be sufficient to carry the burden of persuasion by a preponderance of the evidence at trial. In medical malpractice cases, circumstantial evidence is sufficient to establish a patient-doctor relationship exists.[
8] Thus, circumstantial evidence constitutes proof of other facts consistent with the hypothesis claimed.[
9] At summary judgment, a finding that may be inferred but not demanded by circumstantial evidence has no probative value against positive, uncontradicted evidence that no such fact exists; however, it is not required that the proved circumstances show consistency with the hypothesis claimed and inconsistency with all other reasonable theories. Thus, circumstantial evidence may be enough to survive summary judgment if other theories are shown to be less probable.[
10]

However, in a criminal case, a greater weight of circumstances is required to carry the burden of persuasion as to guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.
“To warrant a conviction on circumstantial evidence, the proved facts shall not only be consistent with the hypothesis of guilt, but shall exclude every other reasonable hypothesis save that of the guilt of the accused.”
[11] For example, the defendant's presence as driver of the car was not enough circumstantial evidence to support a finding of criminal possession of contraband when only his son had actual possession of cocaine.[
12] To say that circumstantial evidence “shall exclude every other reasonable doubt” does not mean that it has to “exclude every conceivable inference or hypothesis—only those that are reasonable.”
[13] The jury determines whether every reasonable hypothesis, except the guilt of the accused, has been excluded.[
14] Moreover, circumstantial evidence may be used to prove any fact in the case, including knowledge and possession.[
15] Circumstantial evidence may also be used to convict someone as party to a crime where the defendant knew of a passenger's intent to commit a crime.[
16] Furthermore, the jury may infer from circumstantial evidence that the defendant and the victim met 10 years before the crime occurred, that they were romantically involved, and that they were not siblings, although no one affirmatively testified to that fact.[
17] Circumstantial evidence may also be used to prove that a defendant is a convicted felon.[
18]

In Baltazar v. State ,[19] police intercepted a “suspicious” package addressed to “Kevin Kline” and delivered the package themselves. The defendant, who was not named Kevin Kline and spoke no English, was confused about the delivery and receipted for it only after being directed to do so. The police arrested the defendant and charged him with trafficking in cocaine based upon finding cocaine in the package that they had delivered to him. In reversing the conviction because “mere suspicion” could not support a conviction under former O.C.G.A. § 24-4-6 (now O.C.G.A. § 24-14-6), Judge Ruffin explained that the circumstantial evidence against the defendant did not rule out the possibility he was unaware of its contents.

The subsequent case of Van Morgan v. State [20] distinguished Baltazar and reached the opposite result. Unlike in Baltazar , the evidence showed that defendant lived at the address where the drugs were found and that he pleaded guilty to conspiracy to sell methamphetamine. Based upon the circumstantial evidence, the jury rejected his explanation that the brick of methamphetamine was in the sole possession of his 16-year-old nephew and to conclude that the defendant knowingly possessed drugs.

Generally, a trial court has a duty to charge O.C.G.A. § 24-14-6 when the case involves both direct and circumstantial evidence and the defendant has requested a charge on circumstantial evidence.[
21] If the state relies wholly on circumstantial evidence to prove its case, the judge must charge on circumstantial evidence as provided by O.C.G.A. § 24-14-6 regardless of a request from the defendant. If the state relies on a mixture of direct and circumstantial evidence to prove essential elements of the charged offense, the judge must issue a proper charge on mixed direct and circumstantial evidence, upon proper request, without regard to whether defense has impeached the state's witnesses.[
22]

In Langston v. State ,[23 ] the state charged the defendant with possession of cocaine because he had cocaine two inches from his feet, he was clutching a $20 bill, and the car into which he was leaning sped away when police officers approached. All the state's evidence was circumstantial, and the defendant claimed that the cocaine was not in his possession. The Georgia Court of Appeals determined that the trial court's failure to charge the jury on former O.C.G.A. § 24-4-6 (now O.C.G.A. § 24-14-6) was not reversible error because the trial court could find that no “reasonable hypothesis of innocence” was proffered. However, the Court has also reasoned that, where the state failed to prove that a defendant ever possessed or controlled pornographic images and the tablet they were stored in, circumstantial evidence, even though it creates a strong suspicion of guilt, is not enough to convict where the evidence did not foreclose someone else in the home owning the tablet or downloading the images.[
24]

However, in Cato v. State ,[25] the court did find reversible error in the trial court's failure to give defense counsel's requested charge under former O.C.G.A. § 24-4-6 (now O.C.G.A. § 24-14-6). The state charged the defendant in Cato with DUI and proffered direct evidence of defendant's alcohol consumption as well as circumstantial evidence relating to his appearance and unsafe driving. The defendant did not deny that he had a “couple of beers,” but claimed that severe allergies and an antihistamine caused his drunken appearance. This evidence, corroborated by the defendant's mother, was sufficient to raise a “reasonable hypothesis” that a substance other than alcohol was responsible for the defendant's appearance and unsafe driving.

In Evans v. State ,[26] the Georgia Supreme Court held it was not reversible error when the trial court failed to give the “charge regarding the exclusion of all reasonable hypotheses” where evidence against the defendant was both direct and circumstantial. In that case, a witness testified that he saw the defendant raise his arm and point it at the victim, heard gunfire, and then saw the victim collapse to the ground with bullet wounds to his head. The court explained that failure to give the full charge on circumstantial evidence, if error at all, was harmless even though there may have been only circumstantial evidence that defendant had a gun in his hand. It was sufficient for the trial court to instruct the jury on the definition of circumstantial evidence and give a full and fair instruction on reasonable doubt. Moreover, where the trial court gives instructions to the jury regarding direct and circumstantial evidence, and properly instructs the jury regarding O.C.G.A. § 24-16-6 , the jury is authorized to exclude every reasonable explanation save that of the defendant's guilt, and its findings will not be disturbed on appeal.[
27] It is principally for the jury to determine whether an alternative hypothesis is reasonable.[
28]

In Taylor v. State ,[29] the Georgia Court of Appeals followed the “bright line rule” requiring that a judge give a former O.C.G.A. § 24-4-6 (now O.C.G.A. § 24-14-6) jury charge if the defendant requests it and the case includes direct and circumstantial evidence. The court explained that, in the case of a DUI, “the opinion testimony of a trained officer based upon his observation that the accused was impaired and a less safe driver … is direct evidence. However, the evidence upon which the officer based his opinion is circumstantial. An accused may fail a field sobriety tests due to illness or handicap and an accused may have the odor of alcohol about his person because someone else inadvertently spilled alcohol on his clothing. This evidence is certainly admissible, and sometimes sufficient, but circumstantial in nature.”
[30] The Court of Appeals has continued to insist that the trial court must give this jury charge where the case has both direct and circumstantial evidence presented, and has held it is plain error for the trial court not to give the charge where a defendant has requested it, even though he did not object to the given charge at trial.[
31] It is also mandatory where the state's case against a defendant is wholly circumstantial.[
32]
Overstreet v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 69 Ga. App. 459, 26 S.E.2d 115 (1943).

However, a defendant may request a “two-theory” charge at trial, which differs from a charge on circumstantial evidence. See Grier v. State, 217 Ga. App. 409, 458 S.E.2d 139 (1995); Kelly v. State, 212 Ga. App. 278, 282, 442 S.E.2d 462 (1994).
Ricketts v. Advanced Dental Care, L.L.C., 285 Ga. App. 480, 646 S.E.2d 705 (2007) .
Dial v. Natalizi, 246 Ga. App. 97, 99, 539 S.E.2d 617 (2000); Ricketts v. Advanced Dental Care, L.L.C., 285 Ga. App. 480, 646 S.E.2d 705 (2007).
Dial v. Natalizi, 246 Ga. App. 97, 99, 539 S.E.2d 617 (2000); Ricketts v. Advanced Dental Care, L.L.C., 285 Ga. App. 480, 646 S.E.2d 705 (2007).

See also Douglas v. Gilbert, 195 Ga. App. 796, 798, 395 S.E.2d 9 (1990); Lane v. Spragg, 224 Ga. App. 606, 607–608, 481 S.E.2d 592 (1997); South v. Bank of America, 260 Ga. App. 91, 579 S.E.2d 80 (2003); Jones v. Baran Co., LLC, 290 Ga. App. 578, 660 S.E.2d 420, 65 U.C.C. Rep. Serv. 2d 786 (2008).
Adams v. Servpro of Macon, Inc., 189 Ga. App. 438, 375 S.E.2d 894 (1988).

Ladson Motor Co. v. Croft, 212 Ga. 275, 277, 92 S.E.2d 103 (1956).
Smith v. Rodillo, 330 Ga. App. 365, 765 S.E.2d 432 (2014) .
Callaway v. Quinn, 347 Ga. App. 325, 819 S.E.2d 493 (2018); Patterson v. Kevon, LLC, 304 Ga. 232, 818 S.E.2d 575 (2018).
Callaway v. Quinn, 347 Ga. App. 325, 819 S.E.2d 493 (2018); Patterson v. Kevon, LLC, 304 Ga. 232, 818 S.E.2d 575 (2018).
Hughes v. State, 215 Ga. App. 6, 449 S.E.2d 547 (1994).
Merritt v. State, 285 Ga. 778, 683 S.E.2d 855 (2009).
Freeman v. State, 329 Ga. App. 429, 765 S.E.2d 631 (2014).
Cobb v. State, 338 Ga. App. 618, 791 S.E.2d 204 (2016).
Outz v. State, 344 Ga. App. 616, 810 S.E.2d 678 (2018).
McKie v. State, 829 S.E.2d 376 (Ga. 2019) .
Baltazar v. State, 254 Ga. App. 773, 564 S.E.2d 202 (2002).
Van Morgan v. State, 269 Ga. App. 715, 605 S.E.2d 120 (2004).
See Mims v. State, 264 Ga. 271, 443 S.E.2d 845 (1994); Rodriguez v. State, 283 Ga. App. 752, 642 S.E.2d 705 (2007); Barrino v. State, 282 Ga. App. 496, 639 S.E.2d 489 (2006).
See also Robinson v. State, 261 Ga. 698, 410 S.E.2d 116 (1991).
Langston v. State, 208 Ga. App. 175, 430 S.E.2d 365 (1993) .
Lindley v. State, 345 Ga. App. 637, 814 S.E.2d 784 (2018).
Taylor v. State, 278 Ga. App. 181, 628 S.E.2d 611 (2006).
Taylor v. State, 278 Ga. App. 181, 183, 628 S.E.2d 611 (2006); see also Waits v. State, 232 Ga. App. 357, 501 S.E.2d 870 (1998).
